I'm a big fan of EDF 2017 on 360 and Global Defence Force on ps2 but I can't really recommend this one.

First complaint, no split screen co-op. I ended up buying 2 copies during a sale so my gf and I could play together.

Second, lame tone/aesthetic. This game was developed by Vicious Cycle Software, a western developer who, from what I can tell, has never made a decent game.  They took the kaiju tone of the originals and tried to turn it into a meathead military game. Gone is the simplicity of shooting and diving. Gone are the slightly too loud sound effects of picking up power-ups and navigating the menus. Gone are the physics that result in bouncing ant carcasses. Gone is the awful dialogue spouted by your fellow soldiers, well maye not gone but not as enjoyably terrible. The missions are longer and this may appeal to some but I prefer the plentiful bite size missions of the previous games.

It's just a let down. They managed to take the awesome concept of "shoot giant insects" and get it wrong. I didn't think it was possible.

11113798.review:
Being an owner of EDF 2017, I grabbed this game during the Summer 2014 sale. The game overall is good, but not worth the price of full admission, and here is why:

Pros
+Graphics
+Engine
+Keyboard/Mouse & Controller support
+Online Co-Op
+4 Different Player Classes

Cons
-Very Short Game
-Singular setting (no Fields, Undeground, Metropolis variants, or Beach settings
-Not Giant Mechas/Godzillas
-Certain weapons are tied to certain Classes

Ok, so overall the game is NOT as good as EDF 2017. Sure, the game looks great, but the designs are highly "western". They've removed those chromed Hectors and flying ships (like in 1950s sci-fi movies) for more Americanized grimdark enemies. Very little color in the game at times, ants and spiders practically blend into the Detroit setting (which is the ONLY setting). You play a very short amount of levels in city that looks the same. No green fields with small buildings, no ravines, no beach areas, no different city changes, no underground missionss.

It plays like EDF, it sort of looks like EDF, but honestly its not worth the current 9.99 price of admission. If you can get it for 4.99, go for it if you're wanting some gun-and-run action. I would not recommend this to 1st timers, but a fan of the series might enjoy it.

10490733.review:
This is a tricky one. After my first 15 hours, I got bored and wrote a rather bad review. However, after dusting the game out of forgotten diskspaces for a second time, I actually found it rather enjoyable and when I got my two gaming buddies to get it, it turned into a blast. (Literally)

So, let's take a look at the game itself, shall we:
EDF is a franchise that was actually around a bit longer, but usually console-exclusive. EDF:IA is (afaik) the sole PC-avaible title of the franchise.
The original franchise relies on 'So bad it's good again'-style of voice acting, cinematics, plot and really doesn't try to take itself too seriously. Combine that with a full-arcade 'omg shoot the aliens' exploding spamfest, and you got a rough draw of what EDF does.
This specific instance of the instance is, as mentioned, the only PC title and, sadly, wasn't developed by the original developers, but by a foreign group. And many fans complain that EDF:IA is nowhere near as good as any of the old titles and a bad joke compared to EDF:2025 (one of the more recent titles).

EDF:IA itself is straight forward: Aliens invade Earth, you are an elite soldier group with absurd weapons utilizing endless ammo, and now fight your way through a 15-mission campaign. Doing so, you unlock more and more powerful weapons, till killing the enemies actually becomes a sidequest next to leveling the entire battlefield. Because that is what you can literally do: Level the (exclusive) city-maps to a heap of rubble. And damn, that's satisfying. Especially because your teammate is a jettrooper direly trying to get into a high spot.
As with it's ancestors, the main progression point of EDF:IA lies in unlocking new weapons for the four playable classes. Not that every class comes with 5-6 weapon categories, with dozens of (often unique) weapons each, from which you can bring exactly 2 to each mission.
Standard assault rifles? Sure. SMG's for the Tac Officer? Jep. Rocket Launchers? Duh! BIG rocket launchers? Too.
Tactical Nuclear missile launchers which fires rockets slower then a hulking heavy? Included. Giant multi-missile 8-tuble super-sized nuclear flare ANTI-AIR rockets? Je, this game goes silly at times.

Of course, the game DOES have a fair number of downpoints: First off, it's limited campaign. You get one campaign of 15 missions, which maybe cover ~3-5 hours. Then you get a 'Campaign Remix' which plays on the same maps, but with different objectives and enemy groupings. And lastly a rather crude Survival mode. The game offers 3 difficulty degrees which SEVERELY ramp up said difficulty: On Normal, you have to put effort into actually dieing. On Hard, you will despare in the first mission because those tiny ant enemies suddenly survive your best rocket launchers and actually kill you in a few hits. On Inferno... let's say I didn't yet make it into Inferno.
Creativity in enemy design is another weak suit of the game: You get Ants. Spiders. Ticks. Wasps. Robots. Then you get Robot Ants, Robot Spiders, Robot Wasps. And another Robot Spider. The game tries to compensate for that by making jokes via the radio. "Hey intel, what can you give us on this new enemy?" "Well, it seems to be... a robot ant! Probably faster, better stronger and more dangerous." "... Thanks, intel..."
And, one of my biggest complaints, is the stupid AI for your squadmates. When playing solo, your team will be filled up (toggleable though) with AI troopers which are... simplistic. They follow you around, shoot aliens with a rather solid accuracy and do their job quite well on Normal, dieing occasionally. On Hard, however, the AI dies rather regularyly, because it doesn't grasp the concept of dodging attacks, or eventually avoiding those incoming instakill carpet bombers. From what I'Ve heard, it becomes completely useless in Inferno.

Which clearly states one thing: This is a MULTIPLAYER COOP GAME, to the core. And boy, once I got my buddies into buying this, we had loads of fun blowing up aliens, buildings, each other and some more aliens. And AI teammates, occasionally. But mostly aliens.
Of course the game has no terribly comlex depth, past organizing a solidly spread out weapon layout, assigning directions/roles to the team (F.e. the heavy battle suit takes care of the frontline, the tac provides carpet bombing support with his launcher and the jet keeps an eye out from above and snipes distant enemies) and learning the bosses' movement patterns to avoid the hard-hitting special attacks.
But the sheer amount of enemies and the intense difficulty ramp-up make the game very challenging, nontheless. (Or maybe the fact one of my teammates keeps insisting on using the 9999 damage missile launcher which oneshots most enemies and players alike, and keeps killing either himself or somebody else.)


Final judgement? 7/10
Solid game, not as good as I would have hoped for, and judging by the countless critique definitely not a high point of it's franchise. But if you get two buddies to play it with, you will very well be busy fragging robot ants for dozens of hours to come. And for a price of mere 10€, this makes it a really nice budget purchase.
If you see it on sale (which I doubt, because this was never on sale, ever), it's a must have!

9728734.review:
Before I get into the game's problems, I would like to say what's good about it. Shooting games where you fight giant insects is a rarity, so points for a concept that hasn't been explored much. The game aslo has a grand sense of scale, with huge buildings getting destroyed as collateral in the fights and huge boss-type foes that are taller than lots of the buildings themselves. It also usually introduces a new enemy or a new vehicle every mission (at least for a while). Although far from a perfectly implemented, the game also gives the player several classes with their own abilities, and the ability to change your gun loadout between missions. 

However, this game has a number of problems. First, it is extremely repetitive. There is very little variance in mission objectives. It's always go here, kill all the constantly spawning enemies, repeat. There's little in terms of varied environments; Where you are on the map has almost no effect on how any given situation is approached. Combat is also repetitive, with waves and waves of the same four enemy types with an occasional bullet sponge boss. Waves of enemies tend to go on for entirely too long, and I found myself wishing for a change of scenery halfway through most of the firefights. As mentioned, most of the bosses are bullet sponges, not particularly difficult to defeat, but it takes a very very long time. Only occasionally are boss battles fun.

The system of armor classes and unlockable weapons is a nice thought, but it is poorly implemented. Weapons can be found on the battlefield, usually after killing some boss monster. However, weapons are also divided into tiers, and even after collected can only be unlocked via leveling up the armor class that uses said weapon. The problem with this is that it can take too long to level up. If you change your armors for the sake of varying the gameplay, level ups are few and far in between, so the weapons you pick up become unused, and the enemies become increasingly durable (the game uses skin swapped versions of some enemies with more health later in the game). Either the game becomes repetitive because it gradually  takes more time to kill enemies or it becomes repetitive by sticking to the same class. 

Overall, the game has some good ideas, but most are not very well implemented. Some people might find enjoyment from this game, but the giant bug novelty isn't enough to salvage the gameplay

9305792.review:
Nesnášíte hmyz? Otravují vás mravenci v cukru? V lese máte hrůzu z klíšťat? Děsíte se pavouků? A při blízkém přeletu vosy utíkáte do bezpečí? Tak tato hra splní noční můry všech co tyto potvory nesnáší.

Je to tak, Země je opět v ohrožení a tenkrát jsou vetřelci obří hmyzáci. Mravenci vetší než auto, klíšťata velikosti člověka, vosy velikosti vrtulníku, obří pavouci co skáčou po desítkách metrů a další výběr ze života hmyzu. Co by statečný voják EDF který musí nakopat vetřelcům zadek! Na výběr jsou čtyři typy povolání, voják, technik, heavy a létající scout. Tyto povolání mají každé trochu jiné bonusové vlastnosti ale jinak se hra hraje vždy stejně. 

Úkol je vždy jasný, zničit enormní množství nepřátel. A opravdu je to občas šílená scéna, kdy se snažíte zlikvidovat desítky nepřátel kteří se na vás valí, pavouci skáčou, přes budovy lezou mravenci, a v rojích se blíží klíšťata připravená skočit na záda a odsávat zdraví. Pak se k tomu mohou přidat ještě letecké jednotky, které chrlí nové nepřátele a ještě vás odstřelují. Do toho jsou občas na mapě hnízda, ze kterých se chrlí nová várka nepřátel. 

K ruce jsou dva parťáci, kteří občas pronesou otřepanou hlášku a snaží se přiložit zbraň k dílu. Nejdůležitější je ale jejich role když vás nepřítel sejme, aby přiběhli a oživili hráče. Ano jsou tady lékárny, ale honit se za nimi po mapě nemá moc význam. Na nějakou munici rovnou zapomeňte, na to autoři rovnou rezignovali, takže jediná věc je přebíjení zbraně, jinak byste ani nepoznali že máte nekonečno munice.

Nějaké to zpestření jinak stereotypní akce jsou souboje s velkými bossy. Ty jsou občas velcí jak mrakodrap a připomínají hráči jak je vlastně proti nim titěrný. V pár misích dojde i na tank a mecha, ale co si budeme povídat je to vlastně to stejné kosení nepřátel jak předtím. Hra se nebere vážně, vtipkují zde protagonisté a dělají z toho odlehčenější záležitost, což je sice fajn, ale řeknou tu jen pár štěků.

Grafická stránka hry je budget jak vyšitý, hudbu zde občas zaslechnete, a zvuky jsou občas otravné díky pazvukům nepřátel. Problém této hry je, že je to furt to samé od první chvíle. Ničíte hmyz, ničíte nově se objevující hmyz a ničíte obrovský hmyz v podobě bossů. A to je vlastně celé. Hra je to zkrátka průměrná, na občasné vyblbnutí a výplach mozků se dá použít, ale nedej bože aby jste hráli více misí za sebou jak já. To už potom ty obří mravenci nechcete ani vidět!

This game is one of the MOST under rater shooters of our time. It doesn't have the best graphics, no... But why in the hell should that matter if your looking for a FANTASTIC game. 

The game revolves around big ass alien bugs and machines, massive explossions that can and WILL level every building in sight. The bugs are BIG, BAD, and they SWARM. If there was ever an enemy that uses it's numbers to overwhelm you, this is it.

There are 4 main classes, and ALL of them are unbeleivably well balanced. Want a Jet pack? Check. How about a heavy with an energy sheild that absorbs damage, shocks enemies, and if surrounded detonates a small nuke? Check. Or how about a sniper who can massicare the massive swarm of enemies from afar without ever smelling them? Check... or how about your average Joe soldier who just HAPPENS to be able to hold every kind of weapon imaginable? Check.

The weapons... oh the weapons. So many weapons and gun turrets and oh, did I mention they have tanks? No? Well they do... and sometimes, you will need them. BAD. especially when your up against enemies that are a little over 15 stories tall and shoot lazers out their asses while dropping giant jumping spiders who happen to have giant ant friends, that have flying hornet friends... and yest they're also giant... who happen to have flying machines that swarm and suicide bomb you when they're too damaged to fight... who happen to have more friends who are just bigger... and Biggers... and BIGGER... You see where I'm going with this?

Oh yes and... there is a rocket launcher that happens to be able to level 6 city blocks... 

But hey if your not into that sort of fast paced, unforgiving, brutal, and adreniline pumping action with 3 player co-op then hey. I guess this game just isn't for you. You probably couldn't handle Inferno difficulty anyways ;P

Besides the typical campaign mode found in most games, EDF: IA also has a weapons & armor unlocking system and survival mode which pits you against wave after wave of enemies, played solo or with others online. The 4 classes vary widely. There is, Tactical (Support), Heavy (Tank/DPS), Jet (Exotic) and Soldier (Jack of trades).
All the classes have strengths and weaknesses. Though Jet gets VERY overpowering in levels 6-8.

The Story is simple, and the dialogue is purposely cheesy (Cheesy good).

As stated in other reviews, there is alot of replay-ability with remix campaign that randomizes that enemies spawn where. The levels you get are limited by difficulty. Normal is 1-5, Hard is 5-7, Insane 7-8. With the way gear unlocks the games stays challenging without being overwhelming.

I would recommend this game as a good laugh. The DLC is with it.

The only negatives I can find is the 3 player limit. (Though with Level 5+ weapons 4+ would make the game a cakewalk).
And that in the wave survival mode you can only play as Soldiers.

7957216.review:
Antes de adquirir este título, tenemos que realizarnos una pregunta obligada ¿Qué esperamos de él? Dependiendo de la respuesta, quedaremos gratamente complacidos o duramente decepcionados. Insect Armageddon es un título puramente arcade, un mata-mata en un entorno semiabierto (disponemos de un minimapa de la ciudad, pero nos topamos una y otra vez con barreras rojas invisibles que impiden acceder a una porción mayor de la ciudad) y destructible. Hemos de tener en cuenta que el motor gráfico tiene sus muchos años, por lo que la física en la demolición de edicios y estructuras no es un punto demasiado fuerte.
Y aquí viene lo importante del asunto. Si esperas un título tecnológicamente atractivo, con una cierta profundidad en las misiones de la campaña y con aspiraciones trascendentales, te has confundido enteramente. Si, en cambio, eres consciente de que los años no pasan gratuitamente, de que ha envejecido ciertamente mal y de que en ningún momento tuvo aspiraciones mayores de lo que ofrece, en ese caso, posiblemente lo disfrutes las horas que pueda ofrecerte.

Cierta variedad de armas y personajes (cada uno con habilidades específicas) que se enfrentan a cientos y cientos de hormigas y demás insectos rastreros gigantes con el objetivo de defender una ciudad y su población es una gran idea. La forma de llevarla a cabo, no. Sería faltar a la verdad decir que no es mínimamente divertido. Sí lo es. El problema es que es una diversión efímera y muy pasajera. En seguida te empiezas a preguntar el sentido de completar las misiones y lo que es más importante, el sentido de no estar jugando a otra cosa. Y cuando eso ocurre en un videojuego, es que algo falla.
Los "final boss" dinamizan un poco el monótono caminar de abejas y hormigas clonadas una y otra vez, pero en seguida volvemos a la misma sensación.

En definitiva, si te gustan los mata-mata cutres sin mayores pretensiones que pasarte horas disparando y defendiendo puntos al azar en un mapa, es tu juego. Abstente si eres de los que le faltan horas en la semana para jugar a todas las obras maestras en su biblioteca de Steam.

This game is basically a bad sci-fi movie by Michael Bay without the needless sex of course. You run around blow everything up and just feel good, because you saved humanity and got a better gun to do it with next time. This is a go to game of mine when I want to have some mindless distraction.

The DLC is over powered and this game is all about over powered so pick it up along with the game, grate deal if it's on sale. It's best with friends but you can easily find a match online.

1243622.review:
Being entirely new to the series, I don't quite know how Insect Armageddon stacks up to the other Earth Defense Force titles. On its own, however, I believe it to be a solid game, doing exactly what it sets out to in a more than playable fashion.

Even Serious Sam has a difficult time comparing to the sheer scale of Earth Defense Force's battles, where the smallest of enemies is at least the size of the player and the largest stand as tall as an apartment building. With hordes in excess of hundreds at almost every turn and the player's arsenal constantly increasing in shock value and near-absurdity, things can get a bit more than hectic.

In terms of variety, EDF is a mixed bag. Much of the combat begins to drag on as the game enters the later stages of the oddly short campaign - doable in roughly seven hours by one's lonesome - as the relatively limited selection of enemies begins to show through.
In terms of weapon and playstyle variety, however, I would draw a considerable amount of comparisons to Borderlands. There are an enormous amount of interesting weapons, ranging from run-of-the-mill assault rifles to airburst missiles that rain smaller warheads down on their targets after detonation. Four different classes, such as the unmatchably maneuverable Jet and the nigh-unkillable Battle, give good options for players of all persuasions.

Graphically, the game is another toss-up. The streets of the cities feel somewhat empty and undetailed and, while undoubtedly pretty to watch and true game-changers for the battlefield environment, the collapse of buildings leaves much to be desired in their wake. Skyscrapers end up leaving little but a neatly-confined pile of rubble, cars explode piecelessly, and the thousands of enemies slaughtered in the campaign leave little but a brief, fading corpse - which, humorously, is often sent hurtling into space by some of the higher tier weapons.
However, much of the model work is definitely up to par, and while the lack of graphical options and locked framerate makes the game feel much like a console port, the game runs flawlessly.

Third party support, unfortunately, seems to be nonexistent. There's not much else to be said here; unless I've simply failed to find it, there's no possibility of a modding community for any but the most die-hard fans.

In the end, at its cheap price point of $10 USD, it'd be hard to turn this game down. If you're looking for something with longevity, that price point may be less exciting. Even still, for someone looking for a quick, frantic, larger-than-life game that charmingly follows every cliché in alien invasion movies, this is most definitely the game to be sought.

2221600.review:
This game is an action packed kill-fest. Despite the technical issues which I will go into further in detail, the game is surprisingly fun, albeit a little frustrating at times. First and foremost, the controls are a little jenky. Plain and simple. They do not always respond the way you want to, however, they are not terrible. The teammate A.I. is horrible. In a game where you are getting swamped left and right literally hundreds, if not more, enemies at once, your teammates ability to hold their own is very important... and the A.I. completely drops the ball. They are inaccurate, will just stand there soaking up damage and dying a quick death and also, for some reason, seem to have an inability to revive you if you fall in battle. This is especially problematic in major boss battles where you are getting swamped with 2 or more boss enemies and the usual barrage of hundreds of normal enemies and when there are few wide spread checkpoints in the level.

All this being said however, the game is unusually fun and entertaining despite these issues. There is something gratifying each time you make an enemy go splat and a great sense of accomplishment when you do actually complete a level. The charterer leveling system is fulfilling as well. Each tier unlocks new weapons, deployables and upgrades, which in turn makes playing single player more enjoyable and less frustrating. The game really shines in co-op mode however and makes most of the technical issues much more bearable. The story is really not anything that special. It is pretty much just an excuse to blow away tons of abnormally large insects, arachnids and aliens... which is just fine as long as you know what you are getting into.

Final verdict: Despite the technical flaws the game is a fun kill fest that is worth the minimal money it costs.  4/5 stars

Dennoch ist es nicht leicht, vorallem der letzte Schwierigkeitsgrad lädt zum frusten ein. Wenn man noch 2 Freunde zum mitspielen hat wird es noch lustiger. Für wenig Geld viel Spaß.

112067.review: EDF offers the full package. It has 4 classes of quite different experiences, some minor RPG leveling and weapon purchasing elements, and a robust campaign. Although the campaign has kind of an abrupt ending, it's not really an issue as the entire point of this game is bug squashing. Do you like choosing between dozens of different types of guns, anywhere from launchers, rockets, sniper rifles, shotguns, assault rifles, and so many weird types of weapons that there's something for everyone. I change up my weapons frequently. The environments are destructible as well, so most of those weaopns will decimate all the buildings as well. I find playing this game very carthardic, as it takes little effort to play it and isn't terribly frustrating as long as you treat the difficulty settings like Diablo ones. Start normal, level up and get better weaopns and more health, then move to the next difficulty. I recmmend getting 1 level below the level cap per each difficulty. Good luck bug hunting!

299112.review: I got one very fitting word for this game: Wicked. Because that's what this game is... Wicked. This game wastes no time on tutorials, explanations, story, any of that shit... It throws you face first into a MASSIVE fire fight against some big - and I mean REALLY big - insects, with unlimited ammo (you do have to reload though), some squad members, and a couple of objectives to complete. A little further, you're engaged by an even bigger alien robot, which is quite a tough nut to crack. For the story part, you'll have to settle with what you can make out from mission briefings and voice chatter, because with all that action crammed into this package, there's simply no room for anything other than the wet weaponry dream of any gun-loving maniac, and a whole lot of gigantic, alien, insect asskicking. If you don't like insects though, you may wanna make up your mind before buying this game; will you get enjoyment out of blasting gigantic versions of them to pieces, while they swarm you?

I was sceptical; Its a console port from an not well known studio.
But this game really suprised me, its a bit like Serious Sam, but with Bugs and Aliens.

You cant approach this game with high expectations, because then it will not deliver.
The graphics are surley not awesome or great, they do their job neverthless.
This is a solid port all in all, keys can be reassigned, resolutions can be set. 
Framerate seems to be capped, not good, but with all the action youre probably too busy to notice it. I encountered no crashes or technical problems... but millions of BUGS ;)

Its addicting, you unlock weapons and levels for your class. You can play the campagin and a survival mode, off- and online with online co-op. (havent tried online yet).

If you are looking for cheap, mindless action, lots of explosions, the ability to flatten whole cities and kill tons of bugs and aliens - this is it.
No thinking, planning or strategy... Just you, lots of guns and the Bugs.
